image.altText: myer window

props.synopsis: The official unveiling of Myer's Christmas windows on Bourke Street this Sunday will not go ahead after a protest was organised to disrupt the event.

title.children: Myer scraps unveiling of Christmas windows due to planned pro-Palestinian protest

image.altText: A close up for a smiling man's face.

props.synopsis: The family of father of four Joe Koumera has been left waiting for answers after he died in the Riverland in October.

title.children: Family waiting for answers after death of PALM worker in SA

image.altText: A woman looking concerned, standing beside a busy road near a primary school

props.synopsis: Regional Victorians say there are not enough crossings, signage, and adequate speed zones to protect school students.

title.children: Calls to address 'road safety insanity' in Victoria after string of school tragedies and near misses

image.altText: Teenage students solve maths problems in workbooks.

props.synopsis: The Victorian government has ordered another investigation — and revealed plans for an independent monitor — following yet another year 12 VCE exam bungle.

title.children: Curriculum body to face full review after 2024 VCE exams blunder

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Patrick Orren Stephenson, 23, has pleaded not guilty to a charge of murder after the disappearance of Ballarat mum Samantha Murphy.

title.children: Husband in courtroom to hear man accused of murdering Samantha Murphy plead not guilty

image.altText: An ambulance in Melbourne's CBD.

props.synopsis:
Victoria's hospitals operated deep in the red last financial year, with annual reports revealing several hospitals did not have enough cash on hand to operate day-to-day.

 

 

 

 

 

with combined deficits of more than $1 billion, annual reports tabled in parliament show.

title.children: Victorian public hospitals operating with combined deficits of more than $1 billion

image.altText: A Indigenous woman wearing glasses, a black jacket and a red scarf, rests her arms on a wooden table

props.synopsis: This year, the Waanyi author of Carpentaria, Tracker and Praiseworthy has won the Stella Prize, the Miles Franklin Literary Award, and now the Melbourne Prize for Literature.

title.children: Alexis Wright becomes first Aboriginal author to win the $60,000 Melbourne Prize for Literature

image.altText: A fatberg is removed from Sydney's sewer system by heavy machinery.

props.synopsis: A group of engineers have invented a protective coating for concrete pipes that could help drastically reduce the presence of fatbergs — congealed masses of oils, grease and sanitary items – that block the sewer system.

title.children: A new invention could wipe away nearly one third of the 'fatbergs' in our sewers

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses and clutching a designer handbag lies on a sun loung and waves a hand and a leg in the air

props.synopsis: There is a list of high-profile Trump loyalists who will land positions in his White House, but this week Mar-a-Lago was crawling with other MAGA faithful who want a presidential treat too.

title.children: A TV host as the boss of the Pentagon, Musk making recommendations on spending. This is Trump's White House

image.altText: Two men in a suit at a press conference

props.synopsis: The Albanese government is pushing for the biggest shake-up of funding and disclosure laws in more than a decade.

title.children: Labor unveils its plan to end political 'arms race', with clamps on Clive Palmer, Climate 200

image.altText: Mr Rudd is looking directly at the camera, wearing glasses and a blue tie.

props.synopsis: The general uncertainty of the looming early days of Trump's presidency adds to Albanese's challenges as he gets closer to the federal election.

title.children: Election skirmishes are already raging, as looming Trump presidency adds to Albanese's challenges

image.altText: Brightly rainbow coloured fireworks are seen over the Opera House in Sydney, Australia

props.synopsis: The "Digital Duty of Care" has the potential to be the most meaningful change to online safety laws in Australian history — even if it doesn't exactly go viral, writes national technology reporter Ange Lavoipierre.

title.children: Confused about the government's latest social media policy? It might help to think about fireworks

image.altText: Mohamed Al Fayed wears a blue pin-stripped suit looking neutrally below the camera's line

props.synopsis: The three women have told the BBC that they were also assaulted by both Mohamed Al Fayed and Salah Fayed, with one alleging she was raped.

title.children: Mohamed Al Fayed's brother accused of sexually assaulting three former Harrods store workers

image.altText: A group of people watching from the street as a plume of smoke rises from behind an apartment building.

props.synopsis: An Israeli government minister says the country is close to a deal that would see fighting cease in Lebanon, but only if it is granted powers to respond to any Hezbollah incursions.

title.children: Israel and Hezbollah are ready for a truce, but a major sticking point remains

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has opened higher, mining giant Mineral Resources says companies linked to Chris Ellison's daughter were asked to repay $158,000, and Jerome Powell says the Fed is in no rush to lower rates. Follow live.

title.children: ASX higher, US Fed not in a 'hurry' to cut rates and MinRes reveals financial benefit to founder's daughter

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Satire website The Onion buys Alex Jones' Infowars out of bankruptcy
Coles and Woolworths to defend class action, alleging 'misleading' discounts
Political heat rising on super giant CBUS

image.altText: A screenshot from a website listing a tractor for sale with a giant red FAKE stamp on top

props.synopsis: These farmers bought used tractors from a website that looked like the real deal. Instead, they fell into a trap laid by scammers using a Russian-linked website to pose as a legitimate Sydney-based business.

title.children: At least three Australian farmers have fallen victim to a sophisticated tractor scam

image.altText: Infowars founder Alex Jones looking sideways, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Alex Jones owes $1.5 billion after defaming the families of those killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shootings, claiming it was a hoax staged by crisis actors.

title.children: The Onion buys conspiracy website Infowars after $1.5b ruling against founder Alex Jones

image.altText: A hand can be seen in the foreground holding a bottle and a dropper full of THC oil. Marijuana buds are surrounding the bottle.

props.synopsis: Medicinal marijuana has been legal in Australia for several years now, but when could an employee lose their job for testing positive for the drug in the workplace?

title.children: The repercussions of medicinal marijuana use in Australian workplaces

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios smiles while holding a microphone on court before interviewing a player at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios has confirmed he will make his long-awaited return to competitive tennis at the Brisbane International after playing only one tour match in more than two years.

title.children: 'Going to be sick': Kyrgios confirms tennis return via Australian tournament after injury nightmare

image.altText: Mike Tyson looks to one side

props.synopsis: Mike Tyson is 58 years old, but will still step back into the ring in a professionally sanctioned bout, taking on YouTuber-turned-boxer Jake Paul.

title.children: Mike Tyson's return to boxing's blood-soaked theatre an unacceptable risk

image.altText: A white man with grey hair stands beside a blonde man in a blue shirt and a woman with brown hair in a grey suit in a studio

props.synopsis: Award-winning journalist Sharnelle Vella and the Western Bulldogs' favourite son Bob Murphy will join ABC Radio Melbourne after Sammy J announces he is leaving.

title.children: Melbourne to wake up to new ABC Breakfast hosts Sharnelle Vella and Bob Murphy

image.altText: A house with Shawline Publishing's logo out the front, there is also a For Lease sign.

props.synopsis: Authors who had their books published through a company that has gone into liquidation say they are thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Hundreds of Australian authors out of pocket after Victorian publisher's collapse

image.altText: Teenage students solve maths problems in workbooks.

props.synopsis: The Victorian government has ordered another investigation — and revealed plans for an independent monitor — following yet another year 12 VCE exam bungle.

title.children: Curriculum body to face full review after 2024 VCE exams blunder

image.altText: Two small fish with silvery blue scales and red colouring.

props.synopsis: The largest survey of Australia's freshwater fish suggests about one third should be listed as threatened species.

title.children: Scientists say 35 freshwater fish species should be added to the threatened species list

image.altText: A black dog stands close to the camera while wearing a harness with a handle being held by a person in biege shorts.

props.synopsis: Peter Frank and his dog are seeking compensation and "change" after two drivers refused to pick him up at Melbourne Airport in 2023.

title.children: Uber being sued after drivers 'point-blank' refuse rides to Melbourne teacher and his assistance dog

image.altText: fire rescue victoria fire truck at station

props.synopsis: A system used to locate and track Fire Rescue Victoria vehicles is no longer operational, with the firefighters union saying the service did not update technology in time for the 3G shutdown.

title.children: Victorian firefighters locked out of stations and truck tracking system rendered obsolete by 3G network shutdown

image.altText: Young blonde man taking a selfie in an elevator. He is smiling and doing a peace sign with hand.

props.synopsis: When your sense of your own identity gets attached to your job, how do you move on when you're let go? Studies suggest younger workers are more likely than older people to be sacked or made redundant. So what should you do if this happens to you?

title.children: 'Am I just young and stupid?' Young Australians on being made redundant

image.altText: An adult lies in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: A new report by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reveals the major causes of injury hospitalisation and deaths, delving deeper into four major areas to identify current trends and changes throughout the past decade.

title.children: Australians are tripping, stumbling and falling off scooters — here's what the latest hospitalisation data tells us

image.altText: A car boot full of groceries.

props.synopsis: As wet season looms in northern Australia, the stockpiling of food in pantries and freezers is underway. Here's how the experts prepare for the big wet.

title.children: This grazier's shopping list hasn't changed much since 1986 — 34kg of flour, 26kg of sugar, four litres of tomato sauce

image.altText: Tourists take part in a white water rafting trip.

props.synopsis: Tour guides have been added to the national Occupation Shortage List for the first time enabling foreign workers with specific skills to fill labour shortages.

title.children: From English barman to tour guide: Elliot is now showing Australians around their own backyard

image.altText: Exterior shot of an old court building.

props.synopsis: A man who a tribunal heard pushed his ex-wife to the ground while she was on crutches and injured her face with his foot or leg has been barred from re-registering as a psychologist, after his Supreme Court appeal was dismissed.

title.children: Former psychologist who pushed ex-wife on crutches to the ground loses appeal to practice in Tasmania

image.altText: A woman looking at medical pamphlets in a chemist

props.synopsis: A pilot program allowing women to get the contraceptive pill directly from a pharmacist is supposed to improve accessibility, but some Queensland women believe it's not as easy or cheap as originally announced.

title.children: A Queensland pilot program was supposed to make it easier to access the contraceptive pill, but now it's being questioned

image.altText: A close-up of an orange electricity cable plugged into a car.

props.synopsis: Vehicle-to-grid charging promises to save households money and get more value out of EV batteries. Here's how to take advantage of "V2G".

title.children: A new technology could help EV-owners save on power bills in 2025, but there's a catch

image.altText: People wearing body paint and animal skins participate in a cultural performance.

props.synopsis: More than a year after one of Australia's more controversial referendums, "where to from here?" is a question many continue to ask. But there are hopes truth-telling will help to heal deep wounds in Western Australia.

title.children: How a process of truth-telling can help heal deep racial wounds in Western Australia

image.altText: An shadowy portrait of Gamitj man and Yolgnu musician Gurrumul posing in a suit with his arms crossed his chest.

props.synopsis: Posthumous albums are typically cynical, cash-grabbing affairs. Not so Banbirrngu - The Orchestra Sessions, a meditative reappraisal of Gurrumul's voice and musical legacy made by two of his closest collaborators.

title.children: Seven years on from his death, Gurrumul's voice and music live on in new orchestral album
